children.subject: And stat 134 and EE 126 have huge overlaps… if you chose 135 it would be way better

As for 105/130, although 130 has a lower workload(no lab) and a higher average(source: Berkeleytime), it is said that 130 is based on some parts of the materials of 105 and elaborating these topics in a physics perspective. So if you were confident about self-learning the specific topics of circuits that would be covered in 130 from 105, it would be better to choose 130.
Oh I didn’t see that you are willing to prioritize EE fundamental courses… in this way, EE 105 as the fundamental analog circuits’ course would be more suitable to you.

There still exist another CS course other than 61C, I would say 170 is pretty much great and useful, but if you are feeling that the workload is again too high, you could also consider courses from 194. They have a “intro to CV and computational photography” this semester, which may be manageable considering your previous coursework on imaging and processing.

Thank you for the advice. I actually petitioned to use EECS 126 to count for my last 4 units of the CS requirement. I haven't received a response yet, but as a back up I am enrolled in CS 194-100 (Social Justice in EECS) which does fulfill 4 units of CS upper division. I've looked through the course content and it looks more like a writing/reading-focused course (not technical at all) and the workload seems fairly light, so I don't think the addition of that course to any of the schedules I'm currently considering would make much of a difference workload wise.

I've  already completed stat 134 and EECS 126. The courses overlapped a lot, but I took stat 134 in Summer 2018 and I took EECS 126 last semester, so the review in the beginning of 126 was helpful haha. 

I think EE 130 is the course I'm going to prioritize, but I'm wondering if adding on EE 105 or CS 170 would be too much. The schedules I'm considering the most are (1) CS 61C, EE 130, CS 194-100, (2) CS 61C, EE 105, EE 130, CS 194-100 , and (3) CS 61C, EE 130, CS 170. I've taken 3 techs pretty consistently and I've taken 4 techs once which was doable, but a little too much. I just know 61C has a high workload, so I want to keep that in mind. I definitely want to prioritize the EE fundamental courses, but as you have mentioned (and what I've heard from others) is that one could learn the 105 material on their own and take 130. I'm pretty decent at learning the material on my own, so if 105 isnt really a necessity for a good foundation then I can take CS 170 instead which is a course I'm definitely interested in as well. I think the only reason I'm still not quite certain in my decision is because I think 105 provides more hands-on circuit design opportunities. I've noticed that in the research opportunities I've had so far, I'm not very confident working in a lab. I enjoyed the labs in EE 16B and I seem to enjoy circuit design, but I just haven't had a lot of opportunities to get confident. I think the course that would actually be the most useful to the MRI research I've been focused on lately would be EE 142, but since 105 is a pretty necessary prereq for that course, I was planning to take the equivalent of 142 in grad school.

Actually I'm mistaken, EE 105 is a prereq of 140 and 140 is a prereq of 142, so I should also take the equivalent of 140 in grad school first before 142. Either way, I still need to make sure I'm confident with the 105 material and labs.

Well 170 is medium light in content, with workload depending on problem sets from different instructors. If you had a good time dealing with CS70, it’s not a big deal. Having a good understanding of 61B is a plus. Actually, I heard people mentioned that his 170 was even more friendly than 70 he took (maybe that has to do with differences between instructors).
About 105… yeah its hand-on experience is also the reason why I stressed on it.(HKN course guide describes it as “a doorway to advanced circuit courses”) I am not so familiar with details of circuits designs so couldn’t provide much help on accessing the feasibility of self-learning 105…

Before any solid suggestions for scheduling, I find a weird point(correct me if I am wrong).
Only 8 units of EE/EECS courses could count toward grad requirements, so your final schedule may have to include a CS course in this way.

history.content: Just want to make a correction on Anon. Gear's first point. If you are an L&S CS major, you have to take 8 upper division units of CS classes out of the 20. The other 12 could be EE/EECS. You could probably also petition if you wanted to take more EE classes, since we're trying to start a new L&S major for people who are more EE-oriented, but it's not quite ready yet.

Hi Everyone,

I'm trying to finalize my schedule for the Fall and I would definitely appreciate any feedback or advice that you all may have.

My Background: 
I'm double majoring in applied math and computer science and I will be graduating at the end of the Fall semester. I decided to declare CS midway through my junior year, so there are a lot of courses I really want to take that I won't be able to (at least not while in undergrad), so I need some help deciding which courses I should take this Fall and which courses I can hold off on. I will be applying to EE phd programs and I want to make sure that I prioritize the more foundational EE courses. In particular, I feel like I'm lacking experience in circuits and devices. 

I'm primarily interested in biomedical imaging and signal processing as well as computational modeling (bio/biomedical applications). I'm also interested in biomechanics (in particular, bio fluid mechanics).

I've taken the following upper divs:

Math 104, 113, 185, 110, 128A, 202A

CS 188

EE/EECS 120, 123, 126, C225E

Stat 134

**I've also taken the lower division physics. 


I'm considering the following options for Fall:

  1. CS 61C, EE 130, EE 105
  2. CS 61C, EECS 127, EE 130 OR EE 105
  3. CS 61C, CS 170, EE 130 or EE 105
  4. CS 61C, EECS 151, 151LA or 151LB
  5. CS 61C, CS 189, EE 130 or EE 105

I'm leaning away from options 4 and 5, since CS 61C + 189 + 130/105 or  61C + 151 + 151LA/LB is probably too rough. I've taken 4 tech courses before, but I know 61C is a very high workload course. If I were to choose between EE 105 and EE 130, which course would be the better choice? Also, given my interests, are there any other courses I should consider?  The only courses I need to take are CS 61C and a design course. Note: I petitioned for EE 105 to be counted as a design course and my petition was approved.
history.subject: Last Semester Schedule Advice
